G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A, and.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, because Plaintiff seeks monetary damages for personal injuries within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Newton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 because the cause of action arose in Newton, Massachusetts, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction, and Defendant resides or may be found within this judicial district.

Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.raw_text: Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158, 161 (1933)
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, keeping, and control of his dog so as to avoid causing foreseeable injury to members of the public lawfully present in the Park.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case is about a customer bitten by a dog inside a department store, not about a dog owned by the defendant or about injuries occurring in a public park. The court explicitly notes that the defendant was not the owner or keeper of the dog and analyzes only the storekeeper’s premises-liability duty to keep its store reasonably safe from harm caused by animals. It does not recognize or discuss any general Massachusetts duty of a dog owner to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, keeping, and control of a dog toward members of the public in a park or other public place.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: "There was no evidence, and it is not contended, that the defendant or any of its agents or servants was the owner or keeper of the dog. … The plaintiff can recover only upon proof of breach of the defendant’s duty to keep the premises in safe condition for her use as a customer. … Reasonable care to keep the premises safe for customers from harm caused by animals is within the scope of this duty."

Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 199, 202 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, keeping, and control of his dog so as to avoid causing foreseeable injury to members of the public lawfully present in the Park.
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 199, 202 (.case_name: Mosey Cafe, Inc. v. Licensing Board for the City of Boston
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 199, 202 (.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns licensing requirements and fees for public entertainment (radio, television, and jukebox) in a Boston restaurant under G.L. c. 140, § 183A and a Boston ordinance. It does not involve dogs, animal ownership, or duties owed to members of the public regarding the keeping or control of a dog. Therefore, it provides no authority for the asserted Massachusetts duty-of-care proposition about dog ownership in a park.
Glidden v. Szybiak, 338 Mass. 199, 202 (.relevant_excerpt: We are of opinion that the purpose of § 183A and of the ordinance is the preservation of public order at public entertainments. ... It is likewise proper that the operation of radios, television sets, and “juke boxes” in restaurants, bars, taverns, and other eating or drinking places not be allowed to become a public nuisance due to noise.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 136A\u2013174E.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with applicable laws, ordinances, and posted rules governing the control and leashing of dogs in public spaces, including but not limited to the City of Newton’s leash laws and park regulations.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7 155.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to comply with applicable laws, ordinances, and posted rules governing the control and leashing of dogs in public spaces, including but not limited to the City of Newton’s leash laws and park regulations.

Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.proposition: Massachusetts law follows the general principles of negligence that every person has a duty to act with the care of a reasonable person under the circumstances, and that liability attaches when a defendant’s breach of that duty is a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the standard elements of a negligence cause of action, including the existence of a legal duty, breach, proximate or legal cause, and actual damage. It further explains proximate cause under Massachusetts law as requiring foreseeability and that the defendant’s negligence be a substantial factor in bringing about the loss, which is consistent with the proposition that liability attaches when a defendant’s breach is a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 9.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury. ... Under Massachusetts law, proximate cause requires a showing by the plaintiff, first, that the loss was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant's negligence, second, that the defendant's negligence was a but-for cause of the loss, and third, that the defendant's negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the loss."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20114.proposition: Massachusetts law follows the general principles of negligence that every person has a duty to act with the care of a reasonable person under the circumstances, and that liability attaches when a defendant’s breach of that duty is a proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20114.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the basic elements of negligence under Massachusetts law: duty of reasonable care, breach, damages, and a causal relation between the breach and the damage. It further distinguishes duty (a legal question) from causation and breach (jury questions), making clear that liability in negligence attaches where a defendant’s breach of the duty of reasonable care is causally related to the plaintiff’s injuries. This aligns with the general principles described in the proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20114.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions — whether a defendant exercised reasonable care, the extent of the damage caused, and whether the defendant’s breach and the damage were causally related — to be the special province of the jury.”

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.proposition: In the circumstances of this case, a reasonably prudent dog owner, knowing or having reason to know that: (a) the Park contained joggers and other park users; (b) the Park had posted leash‑law signs; and (c) a large dog charging at a jogger while barking could cause fear and evasive action, would have kept the dog on a leash, under proper control, and would have prevented the dog from charging at or toward park users.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a premises‑liability case about a commercial landlord’s duty to protect against third‑party criminal acts, focusing on foreseeability of violent crime in an office building. It does not involve dogs, leash laws, park use, or standards of care for dog owners toward joggers or other park users. Consequently, it provides no authority for the specific negligence standard described in the proposition and is being cited out of context for that purpose.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks.… The attack on the plaintiff was not reasonably foreseeable. There was no evidence that the landlord knew or reasonably should have known that a physical attack might occur in the building.”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: In the circumstances of this case, a reasonably prudent dog owner, knowing or having reason to know that: (a) the Park contained joggers and other park users; (b) the Park had posted leash‑law signs; and (c) a large dog charging at a jogger while barking could cause fear and evasive action, would have kept the dog on a leash, under proper control, and would have prevented the dog from charging at or toward park users.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Poskus v. Lombardo’s concerns proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of keys left in ignitions and an expanded concept of causation. It does not address dog-owner duties, leash laws, or the standard of care for controlling dogs in a park. Therefore, this opinion does not support the specific proposition about what a reasonably prudent dog owner would have done under the stated circumstances.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105‑06 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: The duty of reasonable care extends to injuries that are the foreseeable result of a defendant’s conduct, including injuries sustained when a plaintiff reasonably reacts to a danger created by the defendant.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly supports the broader foreseeability principle—that a defendant’s duty and liability extend to harms that are the reasonably foreseeable result of leaving a dangerous instrumentality unsecured, even when an intervening third party misuses it. However, the opinion does not discuss or apply any ‘rescue’ or ‘reasonable reaction’ doctrine, nor does it address injuries sustained when a plaintiff reacts to a danger created by the defendant. The plaintiff here is simply a bystander struck by the negligently unsecured forklift, not someone injured while reasonably reacting to the danger, so the specific “reaction” component of the proposition is not supported by this case.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 61 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: The duty of reasonable care extends to injuries that are the foreseeable result of a defendant’s conduct, including injuries sustained when a plaintiff reasonably reacts to a danger created by the defendant.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a dissent focused on proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of campus security failures leading to a rape. It does not discuss the specific doctrine that a defendant’s duty (or scope of liability) extends to injuries sustained when a plaintiff reasonably reacts to a danger created by the defendant, such as ‘rescue’ or ‘reaction’ injuries. Instead, it analyzes whether rape was within the foreseeable risk of unsecured gates and unlocked buildings. Thus, it does not support the particular proposition about injuries from a plaintiff’s reasonable reaction to danger.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). … The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not include actual physical contact by the dog with Plaintiff; it is sufficient under Massachusetts law that Defendant’s negligent conduct set in motion a chain of events in which Plaintiff’s reasonable response to the apparent danger was a foreseeable consequence and a substantial factor in causing her injuries.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The Kent opinion concerns governmental immunity under G.L. c. 258, § 10(j), and proximate cause in the context of a parole board’s decision and an eventual shooting. It does not involve dog-related injuries, plaintiff reactions to apparent danger, or the need (or lack thereof) for physical contact in a negligence claim. Because the case never addresses the specific issue of liability based on a plaintiff’s reasonable response to a dog or apparent danger absent physical contact, it does not support the stated proposition.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “‘[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff.’ … In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well. … Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.” (Kent, 437 Mass. at 320–21).

Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.raw_text: Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mass. 790, 794‑95 (1987)
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not include actual physical contact by the dog with Plaintiff; it is sufficient under Massachusetts law that Defendant’s negligent conduct set in motion a chain of events in which Plaintiff’s reasonable response to the apparent danger was a foreseeable consequence and a substantial factor in causing her injuries.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.support_reasoning: The case involves product liability for an industrial machine and deals with design defect, proximate cause, superseding/intervening cause, and related procedural issues. It does not involve a dog, animal behavior, or injuries caused by a plaintiff’s reaction to an apparent danger created by an animal. While it discusses foreseeability and chains of causation generally, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific Massachusetts rule about dog-related negligence described in the proposition.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. … Moreover, the precise manner in which the harm occurs does not have to be foreseen. Michnick-Zilberman v. Gordon’s Liquor, Inc., 390 Mass. 6, 12 (1983). The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: As a further direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff has incurred and will continue to incur reasonable and necessary medical expenses in an amount presently estimated at approximately $5,500, for which Defendant is liable.

Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.raw_text: Haddad v. Wal‑Mart Stores, Inc. (No. 1), 455 Mass. 91, 110‑11 (2009)
Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.proposition: Compensation for such non‑economic harms is recoverable under Massachusetts law.
Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses compensatory damages under Massachusetts anti‑discrimination law, including emotional distress and front pay, but it does not frame this in terms of a general rule that compensation for “such non‑economic harms” is recoverable under Massachusetts law. The only explicit reference to emotional distress damages appears in a footnote listing the jury’s awards and does not analyze or affirm any general legal principle about recoverability of non‑economic harms. Thus, the case does not clearly support the broad proposition stated.
Haddad v. Wal\u2011Mart Stores, Inc. (No.relevant_excerpt: "The jury awarded $17,700 in special damages, $125,000 in emotional distress damages, back pay of $95,000, and front pay of $733,307. See Stonehill College v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 441 Mass. 549, 567-568, cert. denied sub nom. Wilfert Bros. Realty Co. v. Massachusetts Comm’n Against Discrimination, 543 U.S. 979 (2004) (to effectuate remedial purpose of statute, compensatory damages include those which are ‘natural and probable consequences’ of discriminatory act)."

Conley v. Moran, 406 Mass. 466, 468\u201.proposition: Compensation for such non‑economic harms is recoverable under Massachusetts law.
Conley v. Moran, 406 Mass. 466, 468\u201.case_name: Commissioner of Revenue v. A.W. Chesterton Co.
Conley v. Moran, 406 Mass. 466, 468\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion is a tax case about the Appellate Tax Board’s jurisdiction, statutory abatement procedures, and tax refunds under Massachusetts corporate excise law. It does not discuss tort damages, personal injury, or any form of non‑economic harm or compensation. Therefore, it provides no support for the proposition that compensation for non‑economic harms is recoverable under Massachusetts law.
Conley v. Moran, 406 Mass. 466, 468\u201.relevant_excerpt: Section 36 provides in significant part as follows: “If, on the verification of a return or otherwise, the commissioner determines that an overpayment of the full amount of any tax, and interest and penalties thereon, due with respect to such return has been made by the taxpayer, the amount of such overpayment may, in his discretion, be deducted from any unpaid amounts of any other taxes due from the taxpayer. The balance of such overpayment shall be refunded to the taxpayer . . . .”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any alleged negligence by Plaintiff would at most be comparatively weighed by the trier of fact and would not bar recovery so long as Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than Defendant’s.

Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.proposition: In any event, under G.L. c. 231, § 85, any alleged negligence by Plaintiff would at most be comparatively weighed by the trier of fact and would not bar recovery so long as Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than Defendant’s.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses G.L. c. 231, § 85 and explains that under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it is greater than the total negligence of the defendants, and otherwise only reduces damages proportionally. That is exactly the rule stated in the proposition: plaintiff’s negligence is comparatively weighed and bars recovery only if greater than the defendant’s negligence.
Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co., 403 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Under applicable statutes and common law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for her injuries and losses, together with statutory prejudgment interest, costs, and such other relief as the Court deems just.

Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 391 Mass. 815, 818‑19 (1984)
Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Under applicable statutes and common law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover full and fair compensation for her injuries and losses, together with statutory prejudgment interest, costs, and such other relief as the Court deems just.
Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The case holds that the plaintiff, having prevailed on a negligence claim against MBTA under comparative negligence, is entitled to the damages awarded by the jury, and it expressly approves the addition of statutory prejudgment interest under G.L. c. 231, § 6B, characterizing such interest as compensatory rather than penal. The opinion does not discuss “full and fair compensation” in those exact terms or detail “costs and such other relief,” but it clearly affirms recovery of compensatory damages plus statutory prejudgment interest as part of the plaintiff’s entitlement. Thus it provides partial but relevant support for the proposition, especially regarding prejudgment interest as a component of compensation.
Mirageas v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “Interest was awarded on the judgment at the rate of 12% from March 14, 1977, the date the complaint was filed… The MBTA’s second argument that the 12% interest rate should not have been applied in this case… [More] need not be said than that the interest afforded by G. L. c. 231, § 6B, is not a penalty. It is awarded to compensate for the delay in the plaintiff’s obtaining his money.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable as of right, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and applicable Massachusetts law.
